elements.content: Electrochemical double layer capacitors can store electrical energy by accumulating electrolyte ions on the electrode surface and are playing an important role in renewable energy sources due to their high power density and superior durability. Owing to the excellent electrical, mechanical, and thermal characteristics, three-dimensional multiporous carbon nanomaterials are catching considerable attention which could lead to the high-rate supercapacitor performance. Here, we present a stable 1.7 nm cage-based metal–organic framework (BMM-9, [Zn2(TPO)4/3(dabco)·Solvent]) with high porosity of 62.4%. On the other hand, after the thermal treatment at high temperature, the three-dimensional MOF-derived micro/mesoporous carbon material BMM-9-900 acts as dual-doped active electrode materials and shows a capacitance of 182.8 F g–1 at a current density of 1 A g–1, and a capacity retention of 98.5% over 1000 cycles. Given the well-established structural tunability, these outcomes will shed light on a new generation of MOF-derived supercapacitors whose active materials can be tunable at the molecular level.

elements.content: In recent years, it is of great importance to develop high-performance energy storage systems such as portable phones and mobile motors, thus to fulfill the increasing demand of effective and efficient power output. Among them, supercapacitors, generally classified as Faradaic pseudocapacitor and electrical double-layer capacitor (EDLC), have attracted extensive attention owing to high power density, fast charging/discharging rate and robust rate capability. Specifically for EDLCs, they theoretically accumulate cations/anions by generating an electrical double layer onto the surface of porous conductive materials, of which specific surface area, pore volume as well as heteroatom doping would impose a great influence on the capacitive performance. On the basis of this principle, researchers have been progressively pursuing porous carbons with high specific surface area and large pore volume for supercapacitors. Although high theoretical capacitance and extensive use of graphene and carbon nanotubes as conventional carbon materials, an efficient, simple and scalable syntheses of alternative carbonaceous material still poses a major challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, it is of great importance to develop high-performance energy storage systems such as portable phones and mobile motors, thus to fulfill the increasing demand of effective and efficient power output. Among them, supercapacitors, generally classified as Faradaic pseudocapacitor and electrical double-layer capacitor (EDLC), have attracted extensive attention owing to high power density, fast charging/discharging rate and robust rate capability. Specifically for EDLCs, they theoretically accumulate cations/anions by generating an electrical double layer onto the surface of porous conductive materials, of which specific surface area, pore volume as well as heteroatom doping would impose a great influence on the capacitive performance. On the basis of this principle, researchers have been progressively pursuing porous carbons with high specific surface area and large pore volume for supercapacitors. Although high theoretical capacitance and extensive use of graphene and carbon nanotubes as conventional carbon materials, an efficient, simple and scalable syntheses of alternative carbonaceous material still poses a major challenge.

elements.content: As a subclass of microporous and crystalline materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have also drawn wide attention for their fascinating and tunable architectures as well as the useful properties in gas storage and separation, luminescence, and magnetism. MOF materials, synthesized by self-assembly combination of both inorganic components generally appearing as polynuclear building blocks and versatile organic linkers, have been utilized as starting substrates for the preparation of MOF-derived metal and/or metallic oxide nanomaterials as well as porous carbons, which can be applied in many applications such as lithium–sulfur battery, oxygen reduction/evolution reaction, heterogeneous catalysis, supercapacitors, and so on. However, multidoping carbon materials with the high pore volume, directly converted from a three-dimensional structurally rigid and cage-based MOF framework, are rarely seen.
elements.clean_text: As a subclass of microporous and crystalline materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have also drawn wide attention for their fascinating and tunable architectures as well as the useful properties in gas storage and separation, luminescence, and magnetism. MOF materials, synthesized by self-assembly combination of both inorganic components generally appearing as polynuclear building blocks and versatile organic linkers, have been utilized as starting substrates for the preparation of MOF-derived metal and/or metallic oxide nanomaterials as well as porous carbons, which can be applied in many applications such as lithium-sulfur battery, oxygen reduction/evolution reaction, heterogeneous catalysis, supercapacitors, and so on. However, multidoping carbon materials with the high pore volume, directly converted from a three-dimensional structurally rigid and cage-based MOF framework, are rarely seen.

elements.content: In this work, we report the synthesis and single crystal structure for a robust cage-based zinc-organic framework (denoted as BMM-9), whose structural formula is defined as [Zn2­(TPO)4/3­(dabco)] (H3TPO = tris­(4-carboxyl­phenyl) phosphine oxide; dabco = 1,4-diaza­bicyclo­[2.2.2]-octane). Followed by thermal treatment under an Ar atmosphere in a Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) furnace, we learn that micro/mesoporous carbon materials (BMM-9-T, T = 800, 900, 1000 °C) are successfully obtained from the MOF precursor at the high temperatures, which turn out to exhibit high surface area and steady performance for supercapacitor electrodes. Among them, BMM-9-900 shows the best supercapacitor performance of 182.8 F g–1 at a current density of 1 A g–1, which is achieved by the synergistic effect between large microporosity and inherent multidoping.

Followed by thermal treatment under an Ar atmosphere in a Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) furnace, we learn that micro/mesoporous carbon materials (BMM-9-T, T = 800, 900, 1000 °C) are successfully obtained from the MOF precursor at the high temperatures, which turn out to exhibit high surface area and steady performance for supercapacitor electrodes. elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were collected by a Bruker D8 Advance using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Single gas adsorption measurements were performed in the Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry 2020 (ASAP2020, where the bulk BMM-9 materials were determined in a clean ultra-high-vacuum system. The N2 sorption measurement was performed at 77 K, and the C2H2, CH4, CO2, and N2 sorption tests were conducted at 273 and 295 K. Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under flowing nitrogen atmosphere. High-resolution transmission electron microscope and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses were carried out under a JEOL JEM-2100F microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Physical Measurement

The powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were collected by a Bruker D8 Advance using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Single gas adsorption measurements were performed in the Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry 2020 (ASAP2020, where the bulk BMM-9 materials were determined in a clean ultra-high-vacuum system. The N2 sorption measurement was performed at 77 K, and the C2H2, CH4, CO2, and N2 sorption tests were conducted at 273 and 295 K. Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under flowing nitrogen atmosphere. High-resolution transmission electron microscope and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses were carried out under a JEOL JEM-2100F microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.

elements.content:
Reactions were carried out in 20 mL glass vials under autogenous pressure. All the reactants are of reagent-grade quality and used as commercially purchased without further purification.

Synthesis of [Zn<sub>2</sub>(TPO)<sub>4/3</sub>(dabco)]·DMA·5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>BMM-9</bold>)

The reaction of a mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.100 mmol, 30 mg), H3TPO (0.05 mmol, 20 mg, H3TPO = tris­(4-carboxyl­phenyl)­phosphine oxide), and dabco (0.13 mmol, 15 mg, dabco = 1,4-diaza­bicyclo­[2.2.2]-octane) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) (5 mL) with an additional 0.05 mL of HBF4 (40 wt %) was taking place in a 20 mL glass vial, which was transferred into an oven holding at 85 °C for 2 weeks. After being centrifugated and washed with fresh ethanol for 3 times, the crystals of solvated BMM-9 were successfully obtained in ca. 55% yield based on Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O. The phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S5). Elemental analysis was calculated for C38N3­O17.3H51Zn2 (M r = 995.81): C, 45.68%; H, 5.14%; N, 4.21%. Found: C, 48.32%; H, 4.44%; N, 4.29%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis Procedures

Reactions were carried out in 20 mL glass vials under autogenous pressure. All the reactants are of reagent-grade quality and used as commercially purchased without further purification.

Synthesis of [Zn2(TPO)4/3(dabco)]⋅DMA⋅5H2O (BMM-9)

The reaction of a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.100 mmol, 30 mg), H3TPO (0.05 mmol, 20 mg, H3TPO = tris(4-carboxylphenyl)phosphine oxide), and dabco (0.13 mmol, 15 mg, dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]-octane) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) (5 mL) with an additional 0.05 mL of HBF4 (40 wt %) was taking place in a 20 mL glass vial, which was transferred into an oven holding at 85 °C for 2 weeks. After being centrifugated and washed with fresh ethanol for 3 times, the crystals of solvated BMM-9 were successfully obtained in ca. 55% yield based on Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O. The phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S5). Elemental analysis was calculated for C38N3O17.3H51Zn2 (M r = 995.81): C, 45.68%; H, 5.14%; N, 4.21%. Found: C, 48.32%; H, 4.44%; N, 4.29%.

elements.content: About 300 mg of as-obtained BMM-9 microcrystal was first loaded in a quartz boat and transferred into a CVD tube furnace, and then sealed and calcinated at the heating rate of 20 °C min–1 under the argon atmosphere with 300 standard cubic centimeters per minute (sccm). At last, the samples were holding at 800 °C for 5 h and then cooled down to room temperature; BMM-9-800 was successfully obtained. BMM-9-900/1000 materials were also prepared by the similar method. The phase purity of the samples was confirmed by PXRD (a).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of BMM-9-800/900/1000 

About 300 mg of as-obtained BMM-9 microcrystal was first loaded in a quartz boat and transferred into a CVD tube furnace, and then sealed and calcinated at the heating rate of 20 °C min-1 under the argon atmosphere with 300 standard cubic centimeters per minute (sccm). At last, the samples were holding at 800 °C for 5 h and then cooled down to room temperature; BMM-9-800 was successfully obtained. BMM-9-900/1000 materials were also prepared by the similar method. The phase purity of the samples was confirmed by PXRD (a).

elements.content: The fraction data were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature, and the structure was resolved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for BMM-9 are listed in Table S1. We employed PLATON/SQUEEZE to calculate the contribution to the diffraction from the solvent region and thereby produced a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The final formula was calculated from the SQUEEZE results combined with elemental analysis data and TGA data (Figure S6). Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with CCDC reference number 1583941 for BMM-9.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determination

The fraction data were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature, and the structure was resolved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for BMM-9 are listed in Table S1. We employed PLATON/SQUEEZE to calculate the contribution to the diffraction from the solvent region and thereby produced a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The final formula was calculated from the SQUEEZE results combined with elemental analysis data and TGA data (Figure S6). Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with CCDC reference number 1583941 for BMM-9.

elements.content: The electrochemical measurements were carried out in a three-electrode electrochemical cell containing 3.0 M KOH aqueous solution as the electrolyte. Our BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, 1000 °C) samples are uniformly painted onto the surface of pretreated Ni foam to constitute the BMM-9-T-Ni foam, which were directly used as working electrodes. The area of the working electrodes immersed into the electrolyte was controlled to be ∼1 cm2. The electrochemical measurements were conducted with a CHI760E electrochemical workstation. A saturated calomel electrode (SCE) was used as the reference electrode and a platinum wire as the counter electrode, and all the experiments were done at ambient temperature. EIS measurements were performed by applying an AC voltage with 5 mV amplitude in a frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz. The mass loadings of the BMM-9-T samples on Ni foam were 2–5 mg cm–2.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurements

The electrochemical measurements were carried out in a three-electrode electrochemical cell containing 3.0 M KOH aqueous solution as the electrolyte. Our BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, 1000 °C) samples are uniformly painted onto the surface of pretreated Ni foam to constitute the BMM-9-T-Ni foam, which were directly used as working electrodes. The area of the working electrodes immersed into the electrolyte was controlled to be ~1 cm2. The electrochemical measurements were conducted with a CHI760E electrochemical workstation. A saturated calomel electrode (SCE) was used as the reference electrode and a platinum wire as the counter electrode, and all the experiments were done at ambient temperature. EIS measurements were performed by applying an AC voltage with 5 mV amplitude in a frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz. The mass loadings of the BMM-9-T samples on Ni foam were 2-5 mg cm-2.

elements.content: By traditional solvothermal method, the reaction of zinc nitrate, H3TPO, and dabco in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) with an additional droplet of HBF4 results in the formation of microcrystalline BMM-9, whose phase purity is confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analysis (PXRD, Figure S5).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

By traditional solvothermal method, the reaction of zinc nitrate, H3TPO, and dabco in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) with an additional droplet of HBF4 results in the formation of microcrystalline BMM-9, whose phase purity is confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analysis (PXRD, Figure S5).

elements.content: We learn the single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis tells us that BMM-9 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̅ with cell parameters a = b = 28.7078(3) Å, c = 43.8106(5) Å, V = 31268.69(7) Å3 (please refer to Table S1), and as depicted in a, the asymmetric unit contains two Zn­(II) cations, one and one-third TPO3– ligand (TPO-2 and TPO-1, c,e, respectively), and one dabco linker. In fact, these uniform microparticles with hexagonal prism morphology can be obtained, which are in an average size of ∼400 μm in length and ∼100 μm in width (b). For coordination environment, one-third TPO-2 can grow into one whole TPO3– ligand after the symmetry operation, further linking to three zinc paddlewheel secondary building units (SBU-1, Zn2­(COO)4­N2, d) where each zinc cation is hexa-coordinate with two terminally bridged N atoms from two dabco ligands (Figure S1). On the other hand, an independent TPO-1 can be extended to connect with one SBU-1 and three tetra-coordinate inorganic building units (SBU-2, Zn­(COO)2­(OP)­(N), f and S1), where all observed Zn–O, Zn–N bond lengths lie in the common range of 1.946–2.093 Å (SBU-1: 2.006–2.093 Å; SBU-2: 1.946–1.992 Å) and 2.056 Å, respectively (Figure S2).

In fact, these uniform microparticles with hexagonal prism morphology can be obtained, which are in an average size of ~400 μm in length and ~100 μm in width (b). For coordination environment, one-third TPO-2 can grow into one whole TPO3- ligand after the symmetry operation, further linking to three zinc paddlewheel secondary building units (SBU-1, Zn2(COO)4N2, d) where each zinc cation is hexa-coordinate with two terminally bridged N atoms from two dabco ligands (Figure S1). elements.content: In terms of bridging ligands, each TPO-1 behaves as a 4-connected node, while each TPO-2 acts as a 3-connected node. In the meanwhile, SBU-1 and SBU-2 are topologically regarded as 6-connected and 4-connected nodes, respectively, thus forming a new three-dimensional network, which features a neutral framework formulated as [Zn2­(TPO)4/3­(dabco)]·Guest (Guest stands for these disconnected and/or disordered solvent molecules existing inside the pore). In the point of topological view, BMM-9 is adopting a 3,4,6-connected 3-nodal net with a point symbol of {4.5^4.6}12­{5^10.6^2.8^3}3­{5^3}2 (Supporting Information, Section S3) analyzed by PLATON and TOPOS 4.0 software.
elements.clean_text: In terms of bridging ligands, each TPO-1 behaves as a 4-connected node, while each TPO-2 acts as a 3-connected node. In the meanwhile, SBU-1 and SBU-2 are topologically regarded as 6-connected and 4-connected nodes, respectively, thus forming a new three-dimensional network, which features a neutral framework formulated as [Zn2(TPO)4/3(dabco)]⋅Guest (Guest stands for these disconnected and/or disordered solvent molecules existing inside the pore). In the point of topological view, BMM-9 is adopting a 3,4,6-connected 3-nodal net with a point symbol of {4.5^4.6}12{5^10.6^2.8^3}3{5^3}2 (Supporting Information, Section S3) analyzed by PLATON and TOPOS 4.0 software.

elements.content: In this structure, we also learn there is one major kind of microsized cage of an approximately 1.7 nm in diameter calculated from its crystallographic data with a calculated density of 0.7513 g cm–3, in which six [Zn2­(COO)4N2] SBU-1’s and six­[Zn­(COO)2­(OP)­(N)] SBU-2’s to constitute a tetrakaidecahedron shown in a and S4. Meanwhile, PLATON calculation of BMM-9 indicates that the potential solvent-accessible volume is 19513.0 Å3 and accounts for 62.4% of the crystal volume (31268.7 Å3). Although it is not a wide open structure viewed along the c-axis (b), this cage-based framework is of high theoretical pore volume of 0.831 cm3 g–1. Generally speaking for those zinc-based MOFs, they turn out to severely collapse and/or deteriorate when the guest solvents are removed during the activation process, while these microporous BMM-9 are a super stable structure that is simultaneously supported with multi-carboxylates and small N-containing compositions, which is further confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analysis before and after sorption test (Figure S5).

Although it is not a wide open structure viewed along the c-axis (b), this cage-based framework is of high theoretical pore volume of 0.831 cm3 g-1. Generally speaking for those zinc-based MOFs, they turn out to severely collapse and/or deteriorate when the guest solvents are removed during the activation process, while these microporous BMM-9 are a super stable structure that is simultaneously supported with multi-carboxylates and small N-containing compositions, which is further confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analysis before and after sorption test (Figure S5).

elements.content: For BMM-9 microcrystals, these deprotonated TPO3+ and dabco linkers act as bridging ligands to connect to SBU-1 and SBU-2 in the resultant three-dimensional framework, thus leading to the formation of nitrogen/phosphorus dual-doped carbon materials after pyrolysis in the continuous argon flowing denoted as BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, and 1000 °C), which can be used for an effective supercapacitor.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and Raman spectra of these as-prepared micro/mesoporous carbon-based samples are shown in a,b, respectively. After the thermal pyrolysis, BMM-9-800 displays too strong typical peaks of inorganic Zn2P2O7 species (PDF No. 34-127) to cover up that of the carbon-based matrix; however, both of BMM-9-900/1000 tend to blatantly exhibit two broad peaks centered at ∼24.8° and ∼43.5°, which are reasonably attributed to the characteristic (002) and (101) diffraction planes for carbonaceous materials (a), respectively. In this context, we assume that there is an intensive existence of a long-range two-dimensional ordered structure within the as-prepared carbon matrix. Additionally, no other impurity diffraction peaks can be found, which implies, after the thermal treatment of the BMM-9 crystals at higher temperatures, these MOF precursors can be gradually converted into carbonaceous materials. In the Raman spectra of b, an obvious D band roughly situated at ∼1348 cm–1 deriving from surface defects, while another characteristic G band located at ∼1599 cm–1, could be also observed for all of these three samples, demonstrating the presence of crystalline graphitic carbon. Meanwhile, the intensity of D and G peaks is very close and increases with the increasing pyrolysis temperature.

In this context, we assume that there is an intensive existence of a long-range two-dimensional ordered structure within the as-prepared carbon matrix. Additionally, no other impurity diffraction peaks can be found, which implies, after the thermal treatment of the BMM-9 crystals at higher temperatures, these MOF precursors can be gradually converted into carbonaceous materials. elements.content: Since we have successfully obtained MOF-derived carbon materials after the pyrolysis, the presence of micro/mesopores in BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, and 1000 °C) is also further confirmed by nitrogen sorption measurement. In c, we learn all of these three kinds of pyrolytic materials are going to exhibit the sharp adsorption below P/P o of 0.01, which is a typical phenomenon with Type-I isotherms for a microporous MOF precursor, but the BMM-9-800 sample shows a compromised uptake of 168.7 cm3 g–1 owing to the existence of redundant Zn2P2O7 species. However, for BMM-9-900/1000, both of the samples give small hysteresis loops at high relative pressure from 0.45 to 1.00 where the maximum uptakes are 394.7 and 398.2 cm3 g–1 at 1 atm, respectively. By using the nonlocal density functional theory method, the pore size distribution (PSD) analysis tells us all of BMM-9-T materials occupy in pore size at the microporous diameter region below 20 Å, while BMM-9-900/1000 similarly have a mesoporous region distribution, as depicted in d, which further demonstrates that the as-prepared carbon materials simultaneously have inherent MOF-derived micropores together with a small portion of mesopores caused by interconnected voids through direct carbonization of the starting MOF precursor, revealing that BMM-9-T can be regarded as hierarchical nanostructures for rapid transport and diffusion of electrolytes in the following experiment.
elements.clean_text: Since we have successfully obtained MOF-derived carbon materials after the pyrolysis, the presence of micro/mesopores in BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, and 1000 °C) is also further confirmed by nitrogen sorption measurement. In c, we learn all of these three kinds of pyrolytic materials are going to exhibit the sharp adsorption below P/P o of 0.01, which is a typical phenomenon with Type-I isotherms for a microporous MOF precursor, but the BMM-9-800 sample shows a compromised uptake of 168.7 cm3 g-1 owing to the existence of redundant Zn2P2O7 species. However, for BMM-9-900/1000, both of the samples give small hysteresis loops at high relative pressure from 0.45 to 1.00 where the maximum uptakes are 394.7 and 398.2 cm3 g-1 at 1 atm, respectively. By using the nonlocal density functional theory method, the pore size distribution (PSD) analysis tells us all of BMM-9-T materials occupy in pore size at the microporous diameter region below 20 Å, while BMM-9-900/1000 similarly have a mesoporous region distribution, as depicted in d, which further demonstrates that the as-prepared carbon materials simultaneously have inherent MOF-derived micropores together with a small portion of mesopores caused by interconnected voids through direct carbonization of the starting MOF precursor, revealing that BMM-9-T can be regarded as hierarchical nanostructures for rapid transport and diffusion of electrolytes in the following experiment.

elements.content: On the other hand, we find that the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) survey spectrum for the BMM-9-800 exhibits a predominant narrow Zn 2p3/2 peak at 1022.0 eV, along with the Zn 2p1/2 peak at 1045.5 eV, well consistent with the result obtained from the PXRD test whose existing form is mainly Zn2P2O7 (a). A similar trend for Zn status can also be observed in BMM-9-900. To our surprise, the zinc peaks disappear and can be negligible in the XPS survey, which can be explained by the evaporation of Zn species [Zn (b.p.): 907 °C; Zn2P2O7 (b.p.): 950 °C] at the higher temperature of 1000 °C (a). As depicted in b, it shows there is a very narrow C 1s peaks in the range of 283–285 eV for BMM-9-800/­900/­1000. And a slight binding energy shift at lower binding energy of 0.4 eV can be detected between BMM-9-1000 (283.7 eV) and BMM-9-800/900 (284.1 eV), which indicates a more sp2-hybridized graphite-like structure in the resultant BMM-9-1000 product also supported by Raman analysis. From the doping point of view, these dual-doped BMM-9-T materials show the presence of nitrogen and phosphorus atoms derived from dabco and TPO3+ ligands, respectively, in which the XPS intensity gradually decreases with temperature, especially for the P 2p signal (c,d). Moreover, what should be noted here is that, though no retention of the MOF morphology after thermal treatment, the final product of BMM-9-900/1000 looks totally different. For BMM-9-900, it possesses the coarse surface with nanoparticles to be uniformly distributed onto/into the carbonaceous layer in e, while BMM-9-1000 tends to have a very smooth surface without obvious contrast in transmission electron microscope (TEM) images, indicating on other residual inorganic impurity (f).

elements.content: Owing to the plentiful presence of micro/mesopores, the highly conductive carbon nanoparticles, high specific surface area, effect of residual Zn species, and P-doped and N-doped feature, BMM-9-800/­900/­1000 are prepared as working electrode for the following supercapacitors. As shown by a, all the three above-mentioned samples exhibit pseudo-rectangular shapes in their respective cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves at a scan of 50 mV s–1, indicating the characteristic of electrical double-layer capacitors. Meanwhile, we could find that the neutral and partially Zn2P2O7-doped BMM-9-900 electrode displays the largest capacitive current response at the same conditions compared with the other two electrodes, signifying a higher specific capacitance corresponding to the results of XPS. Such a distinct difference in the CV curves is related to the particular structures and properties of the BMM-9 annealed in its corresponding temperature. As for BMM-9-900, further augment of the CV curves can be evidently observed, and the resulting current intensity increases with scan rates, as depicted in b. However, the shapes of the CV curves remain without significant change over the voltage range from −1.0 to 0.0 V (vs saturated calomel electrode, SCE) at different scan rates from 2 to 200 mV s–1, which indicates a high capacitance characteristic of our carbonaceous nanomaterials. Similar trends can also be observed in the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves (c), in which all the charging and discharging sides make up pseudo-equilateral triangles.

elements.content: d shows the relationship between the specific capacitance and the charging and discharging rate according to the GCD results of BMM-9-T materials where the specific capacitance of BMM-9-900 is nearly 182.8 F g–1 at a current density of 1 A g–1, higher than those of BMM-9-800 (140.0 F g–1), and BMM-9-1000 (141.7 F g–1). First of all, we note that both BMM-9-900 and BMM-9-1000 have similar higher BET surface area by annealing at the respective temperature and similar NL-DFT pore size distribution curves (c,d), but BMM-9-900 has a better capacitive performance than BMM-9-1000; then we could presume that residual nanosized Zn2P2O7 components probably interact with more potassium hydroxide electrolytes. Comparing with CV curves of BMM-9-800/­900/­1000 (a), we could also learn that all of them exhibit typical pseudo-rectangular shapes for carbon-based materials, indicating the characteristics of surface adsorption of electrolyte cations and/or anions. This might be based on the surface adsorption of electrolyte ions on carbon material and the surface adsorption of electrolyte cations (K+) on Zn2P2O7 and probably help accelerate hydroxide anions transport in the carbon matrixes, while pure carbon materials, for example BMM-9-1000 in this case, show a compromised capacitance performance: ( Zn 2 P 2 O 7 ) surface + K + + e − ⇔ ( Zn 2 P 2 O 7 − · K + ) surface Meanwhile, BMM-9-900 has a higher capacitance performance than that of BMM-9-800, which could be reasonably relevant to the size of inorganic moieties. We can see that some Zn2P2O7 nanoparticles (NPs) for the BMM-9-900 sample are uniformly dispersed and closed to 20 nm, thus being exposed to more active sites for adsorption of electrolyte ions, while most Zn2P2O7 NPs are agglomerated for BMM-9-800 (e, S16), and BMM-9-800 has a smaller BET surface area that is not optimum for adsorbing and capturing cations in this series of samples.

First of all, we note that both BMM-9-900 and BMM-9-1000 have similar higher BET surface area by annealing at the respective temperature and similar NL-DFT pore size distribution curves (c,d), but BMM-9-900 has a better capacitive performance than BMM-9-1000; then we could presume that residual nanosized Zn2P2O7 components probably interact with more potassium hydroxide electrolytes. Comparing with CV curves of BMM-9-800/900/1000 (a), we could also learn that all of them exhibit typical pseudo-rectangular shapes for carbon-based materials, indicating the characteristics of surface adsorption of electrolyte cations and/or anions. This might be based on the surface adsorption of electrolyte ions on carbon material and the surface adsorption of electrolyte cations (K+) on Zn2P2O7 and probably help accelerate hydroxide anions transport in the carbon matrixes, while pure carbon materials, for example BMM-9-1000 in this case, show a compromised capacitance performance:        (   Zn   2     P   2     O   7   )   surface   +   K   +   +   e   -   ⇔   (   Zn   2     P   2       O   7     -   ⋅   K   +   )   surface      Meanwhile, BMM-9-900 has a higher capacitance performance than that of BMM-9-800, which could be reasonably relevant to the size of inorganic moieties. We can see that some Zn2P2O7 nanoparticles (NPs) for the BMM-9-900 sample are uniformly dispersed and closed to 20 nm, thus being exposed to more active sites for adsorption of electrolyte ions, while most Zn2P2O7 NPs are agglomerated for BMM-9-800 (e, S16), and BMM-9-800 has a smaller BET surface area that is not optimum for adsorbing and capturing cations in this series of samples.

elements.content: On the other hand, the BMM-9-800 presents the capacitance for 159.4, 140.0, 128.6, 117.0, and 109.0 F g–1, and the BMM-9-1000 reveals the capacitance for 159.5, 141.7, 131.6, 122.0, 115.0, while BMM-9-900 exhibits 263.2, 182.8, 157.4, 141.0, and 132.0 F g–1 at the charging and discharging rates of 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 A g–1, respectively. As demonstrated in e, we learn that all the Nyquist plots of our BMM-9-T materials show a steep spike in the low-frequency region and a clear semicircle at the high-frequency region. Generally speaking, the intercept with the real axis, the semicircle diameter, and straight line of the Nyquist plot represent the electric series resistance (R s), the charge transfer resistance (R ct), and Warburg impedance (R w), respectively. In this case, these R s values are very close in the unmagnified zone, and 0.84, 0.88, and 0.97 Ω for the BMM-9-800/­900/­1000, respectively. Although BMM-9-800 exhibits the smallest semicircle diameter and the most vertical slope, signifying smaller values of R ct and R w than the other two, probably due to the residual metallic inorganic compounds which have excellent electrical conductivity, BMM-9-800 only provides less active sites for adsorbing electrons limited to obviously poor specific surface area, finally causing the lowest capacitance performance among the BMM-9-800/­900/­1000. Compared with BMM-9-900, BMM-9-1000 shows a slight advantage in the high-frequency region with a smaller R s value and a smaller semicircle diameter. However, BMM-9-900 exhibits a more vertical slope than BMM-9-1000, which signifies a highly conductive behavior with a faster ion diffusion and a lower Warburg impedance. f emphasizes the cycling stability for BMM-9-900 that retains an excellent 98.5% (130 F g–1) of the initial capacitance of 132 F g–1 at 10 A g–1 after 1000 cycles, indicating a good cycling stability, which indicates a chemically and structurally stable architecture in 3 M KOH solution with fast ion and electron transport for our as-prepared carbon materials.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have prepared a super stable and three-dimensional 1.7 nm cage-based metal–organic framework BMM-9, which shows a characteristic microporous material with a maximum N2 uptake of 567.9 cm3 g–1 at 77 K. Moreover, the as-synthesized MOF-derived N-/P-doped carbon materials BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, 1000 °C) can be successfully prepared by direct pyrolysis at the corresponding temperature. Among them, the three-dimensional dual-doped BMM-9-900 exhibits the supercapacitor performance of 182.8 F g–1 at a current density of 1 A g–1 and good retention of 98.5% over 1000 cycles. This work opens up new doors for the efficient production of three-dimensional multidoping carbon materials with promising electrochemical applications such as supercapacitors and batteries.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have prepared a super stable and three-dimensional 1.7 nm cage-based metal-organic framework BMM-9, which shows a characteristic microporous material with a maximum N2 uptake of 567.9 cm3 g-1 at 77 K. Moreover, the as-synthesized MOF-derived N-/P-doped carbon materials BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, 1000 °C) can be successfully prepared by direct pyrolysis at the corresponding temperature. Among them, the three-dimensional dual-doped BMM-9-900 exhibits the supercapacitor performance of 182.8 F g-1 at a current density of 1 A g-1 and good retention of 98.5% over 1000 cycles. This work opens up new doors for the efficient production of three-dimensional multidoping carbon materials with promising electrochemical applications such as supercapacitors and batteries.

cln_elements.content:
Reactions were carried out in 20 mL glass vials under autogenous pressure. All the reactants are of reagent-grade quality and used as commercially purchased without further purification.

Synthesis of [Zn<sub>2</sub>(TPO)<sub>4/3</sub>(dabco)]·DMA·5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>BMM-9</bold>)

The reaction of a mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.100 mmol, 30 mg), H3TPO (0.05 mmol, 20 mg, H3TPO = tris­(4-carboxyl­phenyl)­phosphine oxide), and dabco (0.13 mmol, 15 mg, dabco = 1,4-diaza­bicyclo­[2.2.2]-octane) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) (5 mL) with an additional 0.05 mL of HBF4 (40 wt %) was taking place in a 20 mL glass vial, which was transferred into an oven holding at 85 °C for 2 weeks. After being centrifugated and washed with fresh ethanol for 3 times, the crystals of solvated BMM-9 were successfully obtained in ca. 55% yield based on Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O. The phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S5). Elemental analysis was calculated for C38N3­O17.3H51Zn2 (M r = 995.81): C, 45.68%; H, 5.14%; N, 4.21%. Found: C, 48.32%; H, 4.44%; N, 4.29%.

Synthesis of <bold>BMM-9-800</bold>/<bold>900</bold>/<bold>1000</bold>

About 300 mg of as-obtained BMM-9 microcrystal was first loaded in a quartz boat and transferred into a CVD tube furnace, and then sealed and calcinated at the heating rate of 20 °C min–1 under the argon atmosphere with 300 standard cubic centimeters per minute (sccm). At last, the samples were holding at 800 °C for 5 h and then cooled down to room temperature; BMM-9-800 was successfully obtained. BMM-9-900/1000 materials were also prepared by the similar method. The phase purity of the samples was confirmed by PXRD (a).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis Procedures

Reactions were carried out in 20 mL glass vials under autogenous pressure. All the reactants are of reagent-grade quality and used as commercially purchased without further purification.

Synthesis of [Zn2(TPO)4/3(dabco)]⋅DMA⋅5H2O (BMM-9)

The reaction of a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.100 mmol, 30 mg), H3TPO (0.05 mmol, 20 mg, H3TPO = tris(4-carboxylphenyl)phosphine oxide), and dabco (0.13 mmol, 15 mg, dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]-octane) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) (5 mL) with an additional 0.05 mL of HBF4 (40 wt %) was taking place in a 20 mL glass vial, which was transferred into an oven holding at 85 °C for 2 weeks. After being centrifugated and washed with fresh ethanol for 3 times, the crystals of solvated BMM-9 were successfully obtained in ca. 55% yield based on Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O. The phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S5). Elemental analysis was calculated for C38N3O17.3H51Zn2 (M r = 995.81): C, 45.68%; H, 5.14%; N, 4.21%. Found: C, 48.32%; H, 4.44%; N, 4.29%.

Synthesis of BMM-9-800/900/1000 

About 300 mg of as-obtained BMM-9 microcrystal was first loaded in a quartz boat and transferred into a CVD tube furnace, and then sealed and calcinated at the heating rate of 20 °C min-1 under the argon atmosphere with 300 standard cubic centimeters per minute (sccm). At last, the samples were holding at 800 °C for 5 h and then cooled down to room temperature; BMM-9-800 was successfully obtained. BMM-9-900/1000 materials were also prepared by the similar method. The phase purity of the samples was confirmed by PXRD (a).

cln_elements.content:
Electrochemical double layer capacitors can store electrical energy by accumulating electrolyte ions on the electrode surface and are playing an important role in renewable energy sources due to their high power density and superior durability. Owing to the excellent electrical, mechanical, and thermal characteristics, three-dimensional multiporous carbon nanomaterials are catching considerable attention which could lead to the high-rate supercapacitor performance. Here, we present a stable 1.7 nm cage-based metal–organic framework (BMM-9, [Zn2(TPO)4/3(dabco)·Solvent]) with high porosity of 62.4%. On the other hand, after the thermal treatment at high temperature, the three-dimensional MOF-derived micro/mesoporous carbon material BMM-9-900 acts as dual-doped active electrode materials and shows a capacitance of 182.8 F g–1 at a current density of 1 A g–1, and a capacity retention of 98.5% over 1000 cycles. Given the well-established structural tunability, these outcomes will shed light on a new generation of MOF-derived supercapacitors whose active materials can be tunable at the molecular level.

Here, we present a stable 1.7 nm cage-based metal−organic framework (BMM-9, [Zn2(TPO)4/3(dabco)·Solvent]) with high porosity of 62.4%. After the thermal treatment at high temperature, the three-dimensional MOF-derived micro/mesoporous carbon material BMM-9-900 acts as dual-doped active electrode materials and shows a capacitance of 182.8 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1, and a capacity retention of 98.5% over 1000 cycles.

We learn the single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis tells us that BMM-9 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̅ with cell parameters a = b = 28.7078(3) Å, c = 43.8106(5) Å, V = 31268.69(7) Å3 (please refer to Table S1), and as depicted in a, the asymmetric unit contains two Zn­(II) cations, one and one-third TPO3– ligand (TPO-2 and TPO-1, c,e, respectively), and one dabco linker. In fact, these uniform microparticles with hexagonal prism morphology can be obtained, which are in an average size of ∼400 μm in length and ∼100 μm in width (b). For coordination environment, one-third TPO-2 can grow into one whole TPO3– ligand after the symmetry operation, further linking to three zinc paddlewheel secondary building units (SBU-1, Zn2­(COO)4­N2, d) where each zinc cation is hexa-coordinate with two terminally bridged N atoms from two dabco ligands (Figure S1). On the other hand, an independent TPO-1 can be extended to connect with one SBU-1 and three tetra-coordinate inorganic building units (SBU-2, Zn­(COO)2­(OP)­(N), f and S1), where all observed Zn–O, Zn–N bond lengths lie in the common range of 1.946–2.093 Å (SBU-1: 2.006–2.093 Å; SBU-2: 1.946–1.992 Å) and 2.056 Å, respectively (Figure S2).

In this structure, we also learn there is one major kind of microsized cage of an approximately 1.7 nm in diameter calculated from its crystallographic data with a calculated density of 0.7513 g cm–3, in which six [Zn2­(COO)4N2] SBU-1’s and six­[Zn­(COO)2­(OP)­(N)] SBU-2’s to constitute a tetrakaidecahedron shown in a and S4. Meanwhile, PLATON calculation of BMM-9 indicates that the potential solvent-accessible volume is 19513.0 Å3 and accounts for 62.4% of the crystal volume (31268.7 Å3). Although it is not a wide open structure viewed along the c-axis (b), this cage-based framework is of high theoretical pore volume of 0.831 cm3 g–1. Generally speaking for those zinc-based MOFs, they turn out to severely collapse and/or deteriorate when the guest solvents are removed during the activation process, while these microporous BMM-9 are a super stable structure that is simultaneously supported with multi-carboxylates and small N-containing compositions, which is further confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analysis before and after sorption test (Figure S5).

Since we have successfully obtained MOF-derived carbon materials after the pyrolysis, the presence of micro/mesopores in BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, and 1000 °C) is also further confirmed by nitrogen sorption measurement. In c, we learn all of these three kinds of pyrolytic materials are going to exhibit the sharp adsorption below P/P o of 0.01, which is a typical phenomenon with Type-I isotherms for a microporous MOF precursor, but the BMM-9-800 sample shows a compromised uptake of 168.7 cm3 g–1 owing to the existence of redundant Zn2P2O7 species. However, for BMM-9-900/1000, both of the samples give small hysteresis loops at high relative pressure from 0.45 to 1.00 where the maximum uptakes are 394.7 and 398.2 cm3 g–1 at 1 atm, respectively. By using the nonlocal density functional theory method, the pore size distribution (PSD) analysis tells us all of BMM-9-T materials occupy in pore size at the microporous diameter region below 20 Å, while BMM-9-900/1000 similarly have a mesoporous region distribution, as depicted in d, which further demonstrates that the as-prepared carbon materials simultaneously have inherent MOF-derived micropores together with a small portion of mesopores caused by interconnected voids through direct carbonization of the starting MOF precursor, revealing that BMM-9-T can be regarded as hierarchical nanostructures for rapid transport and diffusion of electrolytes in the following experiment.

Conclusions

In conclusion, we have prepared a super stable and three-dimensional 1.7 nm cage-based metal–organic framework BMM-9, which shows a characteristic microporous material with a maximum N2 uptake of 567.9 cm3 g–1 at 77 K. Moreover, the as-synthesized MOF-derived N-/P-doped carbon materials BMM-9-T (T = 800, 900, 1000 °C) can be successfully prepared by direct pyrolysis at the corresponding temperature. Among them, the three-dimensional dual-doped BMM-9-900 exhibits the supercapacitor performance of 182.8 F g–1 at a current density of 1 A g–1 and good retention of 98.5% over 1000 cycles. This work opens up new doors for the efficient production of three-dimensional multidoping carbon materials with promising electrochemical applications such as supercapacitors and batteries.

Electrochemical double layer capacitors can store electrical energy by accumulating electrolyte ions on the electrode surface and are playing an important role in renewable energy sources due to their high power density and superior durability. Owing to the excellent electrical, mechanical, and thermal characteristics, three-dimensional multiporous carbon nanomaterials are catching considerable attention which could lead to the high-rate supercapacitor performance. Here, we present a stable 1.7 nm cage-based metal-organic framework (BMM-9, [Zn2(TPO)4/3(dabco)⋅Solvent]) with high porosity of 62.4%. On the other hand, after the thermal treatment at high temperature, the three-dimensional MOF-derived micro/mesoporous carbon material BMM-9-900 acts as dual-doped active electrode materials and shows a capacitance of 182.8 F g-1 at a current density of 1 A g-1, and a capacity retention of 98.5% over 1000 cycles. Given the well-established structural tunability, these outcomes will shed light on a new generation of MOF-derived supercapacitors whose active materials can be tunable at the molecular level.
